content:
I've updated the statement based on the comment in the forum: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-anagram-to-break-the-code/203131/5

Main changes:
* Changed "sentence" to "string"
* Mentioned that anagrams are considered case-insensitive
* Moved the constraint on [[s]] to Constraints section

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: its simple puzzle but is very good

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description, consistent tests :]

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good exercise. I love it !!
NIce easy puzzle :)
Nice puzzle. Upvoting.
good

A captivating riddle that requires a careful approach to decode the hidden message. Finding the anagram of the word in the sentence adds an interesting dimension, while creating the code based on the position of the keyword adds an additional challenge. Well-defined rules ensure precise and logical resolution. Ready to take on the challenge of decoding the mystery through the generated code!

Very fun puzzle, upvoting.

* The "Nth digit: (number of words/letters)" definitions at the start of the Statement should state _in that definition_ that it's the rightmost digit of that number, otherwise it's ambiguous
* The last rule should be in Constraints, and should be: [[s]] contains only letters, spaces, and punctuation marks {{: . , ? !}}
Input 
* Line 1: A string [[w]]
* Line 2: A string [[s]], the sentence to search for an anagram of [[w]]
Output section
* Output should be: {{IMPOSSIBLE}}, or the code...
Good puzzle. Letters and words before/after the key is simple enough - except for fiddly rules around punctuation, which may catch out a few speedreaders but nothing regex can‚Äôt deal with.

The statement is clear and test cases are consistents.
Nice easy puzzle.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: interessting problem with several aspect to consider (array slicing, string comparison)
Tough one for the given time, liked it!
not bad

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I'm confused, how here:

7) 9 letters + 2 anagrams in same sentence TEST
Input
mastering
mastering streaming is very important for teenagers
Output
1.5.9.7

does the "number of words found before the key" end up being 1 and not 0 if mastering itself is "the first anagram of the word in the sentence."

Goal section
* Suggest to rewrite the first two sentences for clarity:

You are given a word and a sentence. To break the code, you must identify the key, which is the <<first anagram of the word>> in the sentence.

* Please change "first digit" to "rightmost digit" (first digit may be interpreted as the leftmost digit - it's confusing).

* Please change "all number" to "all numbers".

* Please delete the second rule - I don't think the repetition is necessary.

* Please change "no anagram" to "no anagram of the given word".

* Please state how a "word" in a sentence is defined: are words separated by a space? Or by a punctuation mark as well? In "6) 8 letters + case sensitives anagram" test, the sentence contains "example:in" - is that considered 1 word or 2 words?

Output section
* Please delete the first word "code".

* Please change "d.d.d.d" to "[[d]]{{.}}[[d]]{{.}}[[d]]{{.}}[[d]]".

Constraints section
* Please fix the typo: "ponctuation" => "punctuation".

Case names
* Please fix the typos: "ponctuation" => "punctuation" (4 times).

* Please add pairs of cases where in the output:
   ‚Ä¢ 1st digit and 3rd digit are 0 (no words before key)
   ‚Ä¢ 2nd digit and 4th digit are 0 (no words after key)

Thanks.

Thank you for the review ! 
I updated the contribution as demanded.
mastering is the word that has an anagram. mastering is not the first anagram

For a clash I think it is a little bite tough.
For a puzzle, It is ok...
In my opinion....
Could you validate my puzzle? üòÅ
Thank you üòÅ
thank you very much :)
Thank you very much :)

Uh, is mastering not an anagram of mastering? If so, why is it not the first, and if it isn't (by some reason I'm missing), why is the title of the test ¬®9 letters + 2 anagrams in same sentence¬®, where is the second anagram if it is not mastering itself?

A same word is not considered like an anagram of itself.
Maybe the title is not appropriate... Sorry for that.

I'm not sure anymore, doesn't it depend on the definition? Looking at here.

https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/273628/is-a-word-an-anagram-of-itself

"In the trivial case where you have the same arrangement, it's not another word. Similarly, we don't consider words to be synonyms or homonyms of themselves -- these terms are only used when referring to different words."

That would side with your definition, but note how the comments themselves are contradictory. There is also this:

"A mathematician would call that the trivial anagram. If you want to exclude it, you want an anagram which is nontrivial."

Personally I think this is tricky enough to deserve to be explained in the statement, but maybe I'm the only one in that basket.

Nice puzzle, but you still need to address Rafarafa's concern. I ran into the exact same issues. You appear to be taking the stance that a word is not an anagram of itself. If that is your stance, you must clean up the titles of your test cases and validators that suggest that a word can indeed be an anagram of itself.

And...I agree with Rafarafa that "this is tricky enough to deserve to be explained in the statement". A one liner would be good for me: "A word is not an anagram of itself."
Ok i understand your concern, I did the update accordingly. I hope it is clearest now.

Thank you for the quick response. There may be some misunderstanding, so would you please follow up as follows?

Goal section
* Please delete "The key is the first anagram found.".

* Please change "leftmost digit" and "rightmost digit" back to "1st digit" and "4th digit" (2 times), i.e.
1st digit : number of words found before the key
4th digit : number of letters after the key
1st digit: 1 word before the key
4th digit: 14 letters after the key so rightmost digit is 4

  (My earlier comment refers to the remaining mentions of "first digit". Sorry for the confusion.)

Thanks again.
done.
Please move the constraint to Goal section, as one of the rules. Thanks.
Ok done
